description:
Show or hide UI parts based on app state or data.
Essential for things like login forms, admin vs student views, error messages.
insights:
Tailored UX: Your app feels alive and smart because it reacts to who is using it and what they’re doing.

Security & control: You don’t want a student accidentally seeing admin controls or secret pages. Conditional rendering lets you gate those views cleanly.

Error handling: Showing meaningful messages only when something goes wrong makes apps less frustrating and more transparent.

description:
React-email templates are React components designed specifically to build HTML email layouts. Instead of crafting raw HTML emails by hand—which is painful and error-prone—React-email lets you write reusable, modular components that render clean, well-structured email HTML.

These templates often include styling, images, buttons, and dynamic content placeholders. You write the email like you would a React app, but it compiles down to an email-friendly HTML that works well across most email clients.
insights:
Reusability: Build once, reuse across multiple emails (welcome, password reset, notifications).
Maintainability: Easier to update and keep consistent design.
Dynamic content: Insert personalized data (user names, links) effortlessly via props.
Better structure: JSX syntax helps organize complex emails better than raw HTML strings.
Tooling integration: Works nicely with modern build systems, bundlers, and TypeScript.
